revision.text:
{{Year box}} '''1885 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[American football]]== '''College championship''' * [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|College football national championship]] – [[Princeton Tigers football|Princeton Tigers]]
==[[Association football]]== '''England''' * [[1885 FA Cup Final|FA Cup final]] – [[Blackburn Rovers]] 2–0 [[Queen's Park F.C.|Queen's Park]] (Glasgow) at [[The Oval]] * 20 July — [[the Football Association]] legitimises [[professionalism]] * [[Millwall FC]] founded by workers on the [[Isle of Dogs]] as Millwall Rovers. * [[Southampton FC]] founded as Southampton St Mary's by members of St Mary's Church YMCA. '''Scotland''' * [[1885 Scottish Cup Final|Scottish Cup final]] – [[Renton F.C.|Renton]] 3–1 [[Vale of Leven F.C.|Vale of Leven]] at [[Cathkin Park|Hampden Park]] (replay following 0–0 draw)
==[[Baseball]]== '''National championship''' * [[National League]] v. [[American Association (19th century)|American Association]] – [[Chicago Cubs|Chicago NL]] ties [[Saint Louis Cardinals|St Louis A's]], 3 games to 3 with one tie. '''Events''' * The [[Cuban Giants]], composed mainly of African-American players from Philadelphia, is the first black professional baseball team on a reasonably permanent basis. It will sometimes join a league and use a regular home park but more often tour independently.
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 29 August — [[John L. Sullivan]]'s six round defeat of [[Dominick McCaffrey]] in Chester Park, [[Cincinnati]], inaugurates the modern [[World heavyweight boxing championship]] under [[Queensberry Rules]].<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/achamp.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Lineal Heavyweight Champions]. Retrieved on 6 June 2009. [https://www.webcitation.org/5hNmFEqOV?url=http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/achamp.htm Archived] 2009-06-08.</ref> The bout is described as being "to decide the Marquess of Queensberry glove contest for the championship of the world". Sullivan will hold the title until 1892.<ref name="JLS">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/sully.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – John L Sullivan]. Retrieved on 13 November 2009.</ref> * [[World Middleweight Champion]] [[Jack (Nonpareil) Dempsey]] defeats 12 challengers during the year, most of them by knockouts.<ref name="JD">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/non-jack.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Jack Nonpareil Dempsey]. Retrieved on 13 November 2009.</ref> * Future [[World Heavyweight Champion]] [[James J. Corbett]] is the most successful amateur boxer on America's Pacific Coast and takes part in an exhibition bout with Dempsey.<ref name="JJC">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/corbett.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – James J Corbett]. Retrieved on 13 November 2009.</ref> '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>{{cite web|title=Cyber Boxing Zone |url=http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm |work= |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hg1si20f?url=http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm |archivedate=2009-06-20 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-06-17 |df= }}</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[John L. Sullivan]] * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – [[Jack Nonpareil Dempsey]]
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * [[Nottinghamshire County Cricket Club|Nottinghamshire]] wins the county championship title for a third successive season '''England''' * [[Champion County]]<ref>A semi-official seasonal title proclaimed by media consensus prior to December 1889 when the official County Championship is constituted.</ref> – [[Nottinghamshire County Cricket Club|Nottinghamshire]] * Most runs – [[Walter Read]] 1,880 @ 44.76 (HS 163) * Most wickets – [[George Lohmann]] 142 @ 14.36 (BB 8–18) '''Australia''' * Most runs – [[Billy Barnes (cricketer)|Billy Barnes]] 520 @ 43.33 (HS 134) * Most wickets – [[Bobby Peel]] 35 @ 19.22 (BB 7–27)
==[[Golf]]== '''Events''' * Inaugural [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur Championship]] held at [[Royal Liverpool Golf Club]] '''Major tournaments''' * [[The Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Bob Martin (golfer)|Bob Martin]] '''Other tournaments''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – [[Allen MacFie]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1885 Grand National|Grand National]] – Roquefort * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Farewell * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Paradox (horse)|Paradox]] * [[1885 Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Melton (horse)|Melton]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – Lonely * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – Melton '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Sheet Anchor '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Willie W. '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – Billet Doux * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – St. Kevin '''USA''' * [[1885 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – Joe Cotton * [[Preakness Stakes]] – Tecumseh * [[Belmont Stakes]] – Tyrant
==[[Ice hockey]]== '''Events''' * 31 January — the [[Montreal Hockey Club]] defeats the [[McGill Redmen#Ice hockey|McGill University]] 1–0 to win the [[Montreal Winter Carnival ice hockey tournaments#1885|1885 Montreal Winter Carnival Ice Hockey Tournament]]
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 28 March — [[Oxford University Boat Club|Oxford]] wins the 42nd [[The Boat Race 1885|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
==[[Rugby football]]== '''Home Nations Championship''' * The 3rd series of the [[Six Nations Championship|Home Nations Championship]] is not completed '''Other events''' * Establishment of [[London Welsh RFC]] and [[Connacht Rugby]]
==[[Tennis]]== '''England''' * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[William Renshaw]] (GB) defeats [[Herbert Lawford]] (GB) 7–5 6–2 4–6 7–5 * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Maud Watson]] (GB) defeats [[Blanche Bingley]] (GB) 6–1 7–5 '''USA''' * [[US Open (tennis)|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Richard Sears (tennis player)|Richard D. Sears]] (USA) defeats [[Godfrey M. Brinley]] (USA) 6–3 4–6 6–0 6–3 * The 9th [[Open era|pre-open era]] [[1885 Men's Tennis tour|Men's Tennis tour]] gets underway 54 tournaments are staged this year the tour runs from 2 April to 12 October 1885.
==[[Yacht racing]]== '''America's Cup''' * The [[New York Yacht Club]] retains the [[America's Cup]] as ''[[Puritan (yacht)|Puritan]]'' defeats British challenger ''[[Genesta (yacht)|Genesta]]'', of the [[Royal Yacht Squadron]], 2 races to 0
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{nofootnotes|date=January 2018}}
The '''1st Extreme Ironing World Championships''' was the inaugural championship for the quirky British sport of [[extreme ironing]].
The first event, held in mid-September 2002 in [[Valley, Bavaria]], a small village near [[Munich, Germany|Munich]] in the district [[Miesbach (district)|Miesbach]], was host to competitors from ten nations, comprising 12 teams (three were from [[United Kingdom|Britain]]).
==Competing countries== * [[Austria]] * [[Australia]] * [[Chile]] * [[Croatia]] * [[Great Britain]]; three teams called GB1, GB2, GB3 * [[Germany]]
==Ironing championship sections== *'''Urban'''- Involved ironing in/on/around a broken down car. *'''Water'''- A fast flowing river was the location for this station. Competitors could use surfboards, canoes or rubber rings to help them. *'''Forest'''- Ironing at the top of a tree did not suit all the competitors. *'''Lauda'''- A purpose built climbing wall, which ironists had to climb and iron a T-shirt. *'''Freestyle'''- The section where "anything goes".
==Results== The GB1 and GB3 teams managed to win the gold and bronze team medals. German and Austrian competitors picked up the individual prizes.
Competitors were tested on their abilities to cope with five arduous ironing tests on a variety of fabrics and in different environments ranging from rocky to forest, urban and water. A 70-strong contingent gathered in a muddy field to combine the often mundane household task with "extreme" pursuits such as rock climbing. They were judged on their creative ironing skills as well as the creases in the clothing. The British team prepared for the championships in different locations such as Ben Nevis, Scafell Pike and Snowdon in the hope of winning prizes including a holiday in Hawaii, [[washing machine]]s and other household goods.
==References== * {{cite book | title=Fotheringham's Extraordinary Sporting Pastimes | first=William | last=Fotheringham | publisher=Robson | year=2007 | isbn=1-86105-953-1 | page=12 }} * {{cite book | title=Irony and organizations: epistemological claims and supporting field stories | first1=Ulla | last1=Johansson | first2=Jill | last2=Woodilla | publisher=Liber AB | year=2005 | isbn=87-630-0131-4 | pages=381–382 }} * {{cite book | title=Extreme Sports | series=Games for Your Brain | first=Tina L. | last=Seelig | publisher=Chronicle Books | year=2007 | isbn=0-8118-5708-5 | page=12 }} * {{cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=0b4wAAAAIBAJ&sjid=7f0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=4536,5822429&dq=extreme+ironing+world+championships&hl=en | journal=Lakeland Ledger | date=28 February 2003 | page=D5 | title=Want a Thrill? Try Extreme Ironing }}
==External links== * "Get Out Your Boards: Extreme Ironing May Soon Be Hot", New York Times, May 21, 2004 [https://www.nytimes.com/2004/05/21/us/get-out-your-boards-extreme-ironing-may-soon-be-hot-677108.html article] * "Extreme Ironing World Championships", Natives site, May 8, 2002 [http://www.natives.co.uk/news/2002/0502/08iron.htm article] * "Extreme Ironing" by Really Big Boi (Author), [https://www.amazon.co.uk/Extreme-Ironing-Phil-Shaw/dp/1843305550 book]

revision.text:
:''Bandy Field is also the name of a park in [[Richmond, Virginia]]<ref>[http://bandyfield.org/index.php Bandy Field Nature Park]</ref> [[File:Hänninhauta 2014.JPG|250px|thumb|A bandy field in Finland at the end of the first half of a match. The skaters in yellow vests in the foreground are [[ball boy]]s.]]
A '''bandy field''' or '''bandy rink''' is an [[ice rink]] used for playing [[bandy]].<ref name=nyt>{{cite web|last=Klein|first=Jeff Z.|title=It’s Not Hockey, It’s Bandy|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/29/sports/olympics/29bandy.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|publisher=The New York Times}}</ref>
==History== Originally, bandy was played on naturally frozen ice, mainly on lakes.<ref>[http://www.digitaltmuseum.se/011013013430 Digitaltmuseum]</ref> Teams often had to take time to go out and search for the best ice to use.<ref>[http://www.nordvarmland.com/istid/page.php?id=3725 IFK Likenäs], "Sven Olsson och Rune Håkansson rekar efter bra is för bandyplan."</ref> Soon, ice started to be created on soccer pitches in the wintertime, allowing for a more safe place to play. This may be the reason the outer measurements are the same as for a soccer field. The first artificially frozen bandy field was created in [[Budapest]], [[Kingdom of Hungary (1920–46)|Hungary]], in 1923.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www8.idrottonline.se/DjurgardensIFBandyforening-Bandy/Sponsorer/ |publisher=[[Djurgårdens IF Bandy|Djurgårdens IF]] |title=Sponsorer |language=Swedish |accessdate=25 March 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140325044742/http://www8.idrottonline.se/DjurgardensIFBandyforening-Bandy/Sponsorer/ |archivedate=25 March 2014 }}</ref> In the 1980s, indoor arenas started to be built, allowing for a longer season. The world's first indoor bandy arena, the [[Olympic Stadium (Moscow)|Olimpiyskiy]], was built in [[Moscow]] for the [[1980 Summer Olympics]] but has hosted many bandy events since.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eventtravel.com/Olimpiiski-Moscow-2|publisher=Event Travel|title=Olympinski Moscow|access-date=16 April 2015}}</ref>
==The field==
===The size=== The size of a bandy field is regulated in section 1.1 of the Bandy Playing Rules set up by the [[Federation of International Bandy]]<ref name=rules>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldbandy.com/ckfinder/userfiles/files/Rules/Bandyrules_FIB_Sept2011.pdf |title=Bandy Playing Rules |publisher=Federation of International Bandy |date=1 September 2011 |accessdate=8 March 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130511181936/http://www.worldbandy.com/ckfinder/userfiles/files/Rules/Bandyrules_FIB_Sept2011.pdf |archivedate=11 May 2013 }}</ref> It shall be rectangular and in the range {{convert|4050|-|7150|m2}} ({{convert|45|–|65|m}} by {{convert|90|–|110|m}}), about the same size as a [[Association football pitch|football pitch]] for [[association football]] and considerably larger than an [[ice hockey rink]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thehockeywriters.com/bandy-the-other-ice-hockey/|title=Bandy: The Other Ice Hockey|author=Eric Converse|date=May 17, 2013|accessdate=April 17, 2015}}</ref> For international play, the field must not be smaller than {{convert|100|m}} times {{convert|60|m}}. The field is outlined with distinct and unbroken lines according to section 1.1. These lines are red and between {{convert|5|-|8|cm}} wide, according to section 1.1 D.<ref name=rules/> [[Image:Bandy pitch metric.svg|700px|thumb|center|Standard field measurements, set in the Bandy Playing Rules]]
===Sidelines and borders=== Along the sidelines, section 1.2 of the Rules prescribes the use of a {{convert|15|cm|0|abbr=on}} high border (board, vant, sarg, wand, wall) to be placed to prevent the [[Bandy ball|ball]] from leaving the ice. It should not be attached to the ice, it should be able to glide upon collisions, and should end {{convert|1|–|3|m}} away from the corners, to allow for corner-strokes. The top should have soft protection, to avoid players getting hurt if touching it when coming at high speed.<ref name=rules/> The border was originally only used in Russia, but was introduced to other countries in the 1950s when the rules of the game were standardized and the international governing federation was founded. It allows for a faster game, as the ball stays in play instead of easily leaving the field, which means it would have to be collected and thrown in.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://iof1.idrottonline.se/SvenskaBandyforbundet/Bandynyheter/Classeshistoriskahorna/Aldrekronikor/Sargensentreforandradebandyn/ |title=Sargens entré förändrade bandyn |language=Swedish |author=Claes-G Bengtsson |date=23 November 2007 |accessdate=22 February 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140118050153/http://iof1.idrottonline.se/SvenskaBandyforbundet/Bandynyheter/Classeshistoriskahorna/Aldrekronikor/Sargensentreforandradebandyn/ |archivedate=18 January 2014 }}</ref>
If the border is frozen to the ice during play, this can be hazardous to the players, and the referee can therefore decide to start or continue the game without such border. The same applies if strong wind relocates the border, under such circumstances the match can also be started or continued without border. This is regulated in comment section C1.8 of the Rules.<ref name=rules/>
The border is made of sections which each should be about {{convert|4|m}} long according to section 1.2 of the Rules.<ref name=rules/> Section 1.3 of the Rules prescribes where players must and must not enter or leave the field: Four of these sections of the border shall be painted red on the front side as well as on the backside. These four sections are placed at the middle of the side-line on one side of the field, in front of the players' benches. All exchange of players from both teams must take place over these red-painted border pieces, i.e. over a part of the border which is about 16 m long.<ref name=rules/> According to comment section C3.3 of the Rules, a player who is to be replaced, shall have left the rink before the replacing player can enter the game.<ref name=rules/> Section 1.3 also states that the erroneous exchange of players is to be punished with a penalty of 5 minutes for the in-going player (this length of penalty is shown by the referee displaying a white [[penalty card]]).<ref name=rules/>
===Centre line and corners=== A centre spot denotes the centre of the field and a circle of radius {{convert|5|m|abbr=on}} is centered at it. A centre-line is drawn through the centre spot and parallel with the shortlines.<ref name=rules/>
At each of the corners, a {{convert|1|m|abbr=on}} radius quarter-circle is drawn, and a dotted line is painted parallel to the shortline and {{convert|5|m}} away from it without extending into the penalty area. The dotted line can be replaced with a {{convert|0.5|m|adj=on}} long line starting at the edge of the penalty area and extending towards the sideline, {{convert|5|m}} from the shortline.<ref name=rules/>
===The goal cage=== Centered at each short-line is a {{convert|3.5|m|abbr=on}} wide and {{convert|2.1|m|abbr=on}} high goal cage,<ref name=aba>{{cite web|title=American Bandy Association|url=http://www.usabandy.com/page/show/604524-american-bandy-association|work=About ABA|accessdate=5 April 2014}}</ref> regulated to size, form, material and other properties in section 1.4 of the Rules. The cage may be made of wood, aluminium or steel and has a net to stop the ball when it has crossed the goal-line.<ref name=rules/> The goal-line is the line between the goalposts; section 1.1.<ref name=rules/> The cage shall be of an approved model; the approvement is made by the appropriate governing body. It shall be fitted with small spikes on underside to prevent the goal from being moved by the wind or by minor touch of a player, so that it stays in place. As long as the goal cage stays in place, the match can go on. For safety reasons, the goal-posts shall not have any sharp edges. The goal cage also has two ball baskets, one on each outer side; section 1.4 A. Balls are stored there for the goal-keeper to use when he is to set a ball in play if the ball has been shot over the end line at the side of the goal by a player from the opponent team.<ref name=rules/> This allows the game to start up quicker when this has happened.
In front of the goal cage is a half-circular penalty area with a {{convert|17|m|abbr=on}} radius. A penalty spot is located {{convert|12|m}} in front of the goal and there are two free-stroke spots at the penalty area line, each surrounded by a {{convert|5|m|abbr=on}} circle.<ref name=rules/>
==Condition of the ice==
Especially for naturally frozen ice, it may occur that the ice is in too bad condition to play on. The ice shall be inspected by the referee before the game. If the referee deems that the condition of the ice is too bad, comment sections C1.1 and C1.2 allows him to decide that the match has to be cancelled. No one but the referee is allowed to decide on cancellation because of the condition of the ice (but this does not mean that either team is unable to alert the attention of the referee regarding some part of the condition of the ice).<ref name=rules/>
Deficiencies of the rink, including inferior ice quality, are the responsibility of the organiser of the match and according to comment section C1.4 deficiencies shall be reported to the administrative authority.<ref name=rules/>
==Outdoors and indoors arenas== Originally, bandy was played on frozen lakes, but soon football fields were started to be used, by pouring water on them in the wintertime to get a good, flat and safe ice surface.
Starting in the 1980s, and increasingly since 2000, more and more indoor bandy arenas have been built, especially in Russia and Sweden.
==References== <references/>
{{Bandy rules}}

The country has competed at every edition of the [[Summer Paralympics]] since then, but has never taken part in the [[Winter Paralympics]]. No competitor for Benin has ever won a medal.[http://www.paralympic.org/Sport/Results/search.html?npc=BEN&gender=all&medal=all&sport=all&games=all Benin at the Paralympics], [[International Paralympic Committee]] ==Full results for Benin at the Paralympics== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:90%" |- !Name !Games !Sport !Event !Score !Rank |- | [[Edouard Agboessi]] || [[2000 Summer Paralympics|2000 Sydney]] || [[Athletics at the 2000 Summer Paralympics|Athletics]] || Men's 100 m T11 || 13.42 || 2nd in heat 1;

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} {{refimprove|date=September 2009}} {{Globalize/UK|date=January 2011}} [[File:King Kenny vs Bolton 2011.jpg|thumb|right|202px|[[Kenny Dalglish]] temporarily served as the caretaker manager of [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] in 2011, following the sacking of [[Roy Hodgson]]. He was eventually promoted to permanent manager.]]
In [[association football]]ing terms, a '''caretaker manager''' is somebody who takes temporary charge of the management of a [[football club]], usually when the regular [[Manager (association football)|manager]] is dismissed, or leaves for a different club. However, a caretaker may also be appointed if the regular manager is suspended, ill or unable to attend to their usual duties. Caretaker managers are normally appointed at short notice from within the club, usually the assistant manager, a senior coach, or an experienced player. In other sports, the term "interim manager" is more commonly used.
==Caretaker managers in Eastern Europe== Caretaker managers in Eastern Europe are [[head coach]]es that carry prefix title '''performing duties''' or sometimes temporary performing duties. These managers do not have a required license ([[UEFA Pro Licence]]) to be full pledged head coaches (managers).
==Caretaker managers in practice== Famous examples include long-standing [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] assistant manager [[Stewart Houston]], who stepped in after [[George Graham (footballer)|George Graham]] was abruptly sacked in the middle of the [[1994-95 in English football|1994–95]] season and guided the club to the [[1995 UEFA Cup Winners' Cup Final|1995 European Cup Winners' Cup Final]]. [[Tony Barton (footballer)|Tony Barton]] was appointed manager of [[Aston Villa]] after the departure of [[Ron Saunders]] and led the club to win the 1982 [[UEFA Champions League|European Cup]] after only three months in charge. Club Director [[Trevor Brooking]] was appointed as caretaker manager of [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] following [[Glenn Roeder]]'s illness at the end of the [[2002-03 in English football|2002–03 season]], then again following his dismissal early in the [[2003-04 in English football|2003–04 season]].
==Permanent appointments== If a caretaker proves to be particularly successful during their spell in charge, they are sometimes given the manager's job permanently. [[Glenn Roeder]] was appointed permanent manager of [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] after having taken over as caretaker following [[Graeme Souness]]' dismissal in 2006. This also occurred when [[Ricky Sbragia]] got the [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] job permanently after [[Roy Keane]]'s resignation in November 2008 but he resigned himself at the end of the season [[2008-09 in English football|2008–09]]. This also happened in the [[2010–11 Premier League]]; on 8 January 2011, [[Roy Hodgson]] was sacked by [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] after a run of poor results, and with Liverpool languishing in 12th place, [[Kenny Dalglish]] was appointed the caretaker manager of Liverpool for the remainder of the season. After an impressive run of results, which saw Liverpool rise to 6th on the table, Dalglish was appointed the permanent manager of Liverpool, on a three-year contract.
In Norway, a notable example occurred in [[Norwegian Premier League 2006|2006]] when [[Rosenborg BK]] manager [[Per-Mathias Høgmo]] announced he was taking a leave of absence in mid-season, citing health concerns. At the time, Rosenborg were ten points behind leaders [[S.K. Brann|SK Brann]]. His assistant [[Knut Tørum]] was appointed on an interim basis, and proceeded to lead Rosenborg to a furious comeback, clinching the league title with one match to spare. Høgmo announced his resignation two days after Rosenborg clinched, and Tørum was named permanent manager after the season.
On the other hand, [[Tony Parkes]] was named caretaker manager of [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] on six separate occasions between 1986 and 2004, without ever being given the role in a permanent capacity. He is still yet to be given a permanent managerial role.
==Notable success== In November 2007, [[Sandy Stewart (footballer)|Sandy Stewart]] led [[St Johnstone F.C.|St Johnstone]] to victory in the final of the [[Scottish Challenge Cup]] in his only game in charge as caretaker manager.<ref>[http://www.stjohnstonefc.co.uk/newsitem.asp?NewsID=2300 "Cup glory for Saints!!!"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720082530/http://www.stjohnstonefc.co.uk/newsitem.asp?NewsID=2300 |date=20 July 2011 }} St Johnstone FC Official website</ref>
In the [[2007–08 Süper Lig|2007–08 season]], [[Cevat Güler]] won [[Süper Lig]] as [[Galatasaray S.K. (football)|Galatasaray]]'s caretaker manager. He was in charge for the last five matches of the season due to [[Karl Heinz Feldkamp]]'s resignation.
In the 2007 [[Hazfi Cup]] [[2007 Hazfi Cup Final|final]], [[Sepahan F.C.|Sepahan]]'s head coach, [[Luka Bonačić]] had travelled to his country, [[Croatia]] for personal reasons and was unavailable to manage the team in the second leg. [[Mansour Ebrahimzadeh]] who was assistant to Bonačić served as caretaker manager for that match. Sepahan won the match and the title.
[[Guus Hiddink]] was caretaker manager of [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] in 2009, leading his team to the semi-final of the UEFA Champions League where they shut out [[FC Barcelona]] at [[Camp Nou]] and tied them back at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]] (the latter being a very controversial game, the match official being [[Tom Henning Øvrebø]], with Chelsea eliminated on away goals), and finished off his tenure with the team as they won the [[FA Cup]] The club was reported happy to have Hiddink as manager even on a temporary basis.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mirrorfootball.co.uk/news/How-Guus-Hiddink-will-leave-incoming-Chelsea-boss-Carlo-Ancelotti-a-fine-legacy-article26669.html|title=Football News - all the latest breaking football stories - Mirror Online|author=|date=|website=www.mirrorfootball.co.uk|accessdate=8 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120129232039/http://www.mirrorfootball.co.uk/news/How-Guus-Hiddink-will-leave-incoming-Chelsea-boss-Carlo-Ancelotti-a-fine-legacy-article26669.html|archivedate=29 January 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
[[Roberto Di Matteo]] won the [[UEFA Champions League 2011–12|Champions League]] and [[2011-12 FA Cup|FA Cup]] as caretaker manager of [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] in 2012, leading to him being appointed permanent manager on a two-year contract. He was sacked a few months into the new season,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/20423905|title=Roberto Di Matteo sacked by Chelsea after Juventus defeat|author=|date=21 November 2012|publisher=|accessdate=8 May 2018|via=www.bbc.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180212213348/http://www.bbc.com/sport/football/20423905|archivedate=12 February 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> being replaced by another caretaker manager, [[Rafael Benítez]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/20427966|title=Rafael Benitez replaces Roberto Di Matteo as Chelsea manager|author=|date=21 November 2012|publisher=|accessdate=8 May 2018|via=www.bbc.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180421000539/https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/20427966|archivedate=21 April 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> who led his team to victory in the [[UEFA Europa League 2012-13|Europa League]], as well as guiding the team to a third-place finish in the league,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.statto.com/football/stats/england/premier-league/2012-2013/table |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-08-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160821221615/http://www.statto.com/football/stats/england/premier-league/2012-2013/table |archivedate=21 August 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> thus ensuring direct qualification for next year's Champions League. Benítez was not offered a contract as permanent manager, instead being replaced by [[José Mourinho]] who went back to Chelsea for a second term.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.si.com/soccer/2013/06/03/jose-mourinho-chelsea|title=Chelsea hires Jose Mourinho as manager again|author=|date=|website=si.com|accessdate=8 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170710063355/https://www.si.com/soccer/2013/06/03/jose-mourinho-chelsea|archivedate=10 July 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox football club | clubname = Colo-Colo | image = Colo-Colo.svg | image_size = 180px | fullname = Club Social y Deportivo Colo-Colo | founded = {{Start date and years ago|df=yes|1925|4|19}} | nickname = "Los Albos"

Gabriel Ruiz-Tagle (Blanco y Negro S.A.) | manager = [[Marcelo Espina]] | coach = [[Héctor Tapia]] | league = [[Chilean Primera División]] | season = [[2017 Chilean Primera División|2017 Transición]] | position = 1st | website = http://www.colocolo.cl | current = |pattern_la1 = _colocolo18h|pattern_b1 = _colocolo18h|pattern_ra1 =_colocolo18h |pattern_sh1 = _colocolo18h |pattern_so1 = _colocolo18h |leftarm1 = FFFFFF |body1 = FFFFFF |rightarm1 = FFFFFF |shorts1 = 000000 |socks1 = FFFFFF |pattern_la2 = _colocolo18h |pattern_b2 = _colocolo18a|pattern_ra2 = _colocolo18h |pattern_sh2 = _colocolo18h |pattern_so2 = _colocolo18a |leftarm2 = 000000 |body2 = 000000 |rightarm2 = 000000 |shorts2 = 000000 |socks2 = 000000 |pattern_la3 = _colocolo18h|pattern_b3 = _colocolo18t|pattern_ra3 =_colocolo18h |pattern_sh3 = _colocolo18h |pattern_so3 = _colocolo18h |leftarm3 = FFFFFF |body3 = FFFFFF |rightarm3 = FFFFFF |shorts3 = 000000 |socks3 = FFFFFF }} '''Club Social y Deportivo Colo-Colo''' ({{IPA-es|ˌkolo ˈkolo|pronunciation}}) is a [[Chile]]an [[Association football|football]] club based in [[Macul]], [[Santiago]]. Founded in 1925, they play in the [[Chilean Primera División]], from which they have [[List of unrelegated association football clubs|never been relegated]].{{cite web |url = http://www.elgraficochile.cl/la-selecta-lista-de-los-equipos-sudamericanos-que-nunca-han-descendido/prontus_elgrafico/2012-08-29/124315.html |title = La selecta lista de los equipos sudamericanos que nunca han descendido |publisher = El Gráfico |work= Elgrafico.cl |language = Spanish | date = 29 August 2012 |accessdate = 22 September 2014}} The team has played its home games at [[Estadio Monumental David Arellano]] since 1989.{{cite web |author = |year = 2009 |url = http://www.colocolo.cl/2009/09/una-jornada-monumental/ |title = ¡Feliz Cumpleaños, Estadio Monumental! |work= Sitio Oficial de Colo-Colo |language = Spanish |accessdate = 17 June 2011}} Colo-Colo is regarded as the most successful club of Chilean football. Colo-Colo has won more [[Primera División de Chile]] (32) than any other Chilean club and a record eleven [[Copa Chile]] titles. It was the first Chilean team to win a continental tournament conquering the [[1991 Copa Libertadores]]{{cite web |url = http://www.cooperativa.cl/noticias/deportes/futbol/colo-colo/colo-colo-recuerda-la-gloriosa-jornada-en-que-conquisto-la-copa-libertadores/2011-06-04/214400.html |title = Colo Colo recuerda la gloriosa jornada en que conquistó la Copa Libertadores |publisher = Emol | work= Emol.com | date = 5 June 2011 |accessdate = 22 September 2014 |language = Spanish}} after beating [[Club Olimpia]] 3–0 on 5 June with [[Mirko Jozić]] as manager. Next year, the club went on to win two international titles that were [[1992 Recopa Sudamericana]]{{cite web|url = http://charlatecnica.cl/2012/08/hace-20-anos-colo-colo-trajo-la-recopa-sudamericana-a-chile/ |title = Hace 20 años, Colo Colo trajo la Recopa Sudamericana a Chile |publisher = Charla Técnica | work= Charlatecnica.cl | date = 21 August 2012 |accessdate = 22 September 2014 |language = Spanish}} and [[1992 Copa Interamericana]],{{cite web|url = http://www.dalealbo.cl/foro/historia-del-club-social-y-deportivo-colo-colo/93315-23-de-septiembre-de-1992-colo-colo-campeon-copa-interamericana.html |title = Colo Colo Campeón Copa Interamericana |publisher = Dale Albo| work= Dalealbo.cl | date = 23 September 2011 |accessdate = 22 September 2014 |language = Spanish}} completing the club's three international honours. The club's most successful player is [[Luis Mena Irarrázabal|Luis Mena]] with eleven titles,{{cite web | title = Jugadores con mas Ganadores (Títulos) | url = http://www.dalealbo.cl/foro/historia-del-club-social-y-deportivo-colo-colo/71648-jugadores-mas-ganadores-con-mas-titulos.html | work = Dalealbo.cl |accessdate=23 March 2013 }} the historic top scorer is [[Francisco Valdés]] with 208 goals,{{cite web | title = Muere Francisco Valdés, goleador histórico del fútbol chileno | url = http://www.latercera.com/contenido/688_167220_9.shtml | publisher = La Tercera | date = 18 August 2009 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20091016094902/http://www.latercera.com/contenido/688_167220_9.shtml | archivedate = 16 October 2009 | df = }} and the player with most appearances is the former goalkeeper [[Misael Escuti]] with 417 games. Colo-Colo is the team with most supporters in Chile,{{cite web | title = Colo-Colo es el equipo más popular| url = http://www.lanacion.cl/prontus_noticias_v2/site/artic/20090130/pags/20090130201049.html | newspaper = La Nación |accessdate=6 February 2013 }} and holds a long-standing rivalry with [[Club Universidad de Chile]]. The club also holds a traditional rivalry in matches against [[C.D. Cobreloa]] and [[Club Deportivo Universidad Católica]]. The [[IFFHS]] ranked the team in 14th place in [[2007 Colo-Colo season|2007]].{{cite web | title = IFFHS' 2007 Ranking | url = http://iffhs.de:80/?eedbca388d85691a55685fdcdc3bfcdc0aec70a10e | archivedate=26 January 2009 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090126215836/http://iffhs.de:80/?eedbca388d85691a55685fdcdc3bfcdc0aec70a10e | publisher = [[IFFHS]].com |accessdate=11 August 2017 }} In [[2009 Colo-Colo season|2009]], that same institution named the team as the 20th century's top club of its country, and also within the top twenty clubs in South American football history.{{cite web |publisher = IFFHS |url = http://www.iffhs.de/?32b0cfd380ff73117fe2c0bf23c17e23a09e33b17f7370eff3702bb1c2bbb6e20e52c00f23808f15 |title = South America‘s Club of the Century | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091001005452/http://www.iffhs.de/?32b0cfd380ff73117fe2c0bf23c17e23a09e33b17f7370eff3702bb1c2bbb6e20e52c00f23808f15 | archivedate=1 October 2009 | accessdate = 11 August 2017 }} ==History== ===1925–1933: Foundation and early years=== [[File:David Arellano.PNG|thumb|160px|left|[[David Arellano]], the founder of the club]] [[File:Colo-Colo 1925.jpg|thumb|right|250px|One of the first Colo-Colo line-ups, 1925]] The team was founded in early 1925 by [[C.D. Magallanes|Magallanes]]' footballer [[David Arellano]], who led a group of young players leaving that club after institutional problems.Salinas, Sebastián (2005), p. 37.Salinas, Sebastián (2005), p. 52. Finally, on 19 April, Arellano and the other youths officially established the institutions after meetings and negotiations, where Luis Contreras chose the name Colo-Colo for the club,Salinas, Sebastián (2005), p. 44. which refers to the eponymous [[Mapuche]] cacique [[Colocolo (tribal chief)|Colo Colo]]. The team began to play friendly games, but in 1926, Colo-Colo took part in the [[Primera División de Chile|Metropolitan League of Honour]], where they were proclaimed champions (in unbeaten way) and earned the nickname of "invincible".Salinas, Sebastián (2005), p. 53. The following year, Colo-Colo became the first Chilean football team to participate in a tour across Europe. However, on 2 May, during an exhibition match against [[Real Valladolid|Real Unión Deportiva]] at [[Valladolid]], the team founder and captain David Arellano was critically injured after suffering a collision with an opposing player, which caused him [[peritonitis]].Salinas, Sebastián (2005), p. 70. The inflammation led him to his death the next day.{{cite web |publisher = Los Sports |date = 1925–1927 |url = http://www.memoriachilena.cl/archivos2/pdfs/MC0006536.pdf |title = Los domingos footballísticos |work = Zig-Zag |accessdate = 17 March 2013}} Despite the great impact caused by Arellano’s death, the club won the [[Chilean Primera División|Central League of football]] tournament – then renamed [[Asociación de Fútbol de Santiago|Asociación de Football de Santiago]] – in the 1928,Salinas, Sebastián (2005), p. 184. 1929Salinas, Sebastián (2005), p. 215. and 1930Salinas, Sebastián (2005), p. 245. seasons. In the 1931–32 season, Colo-Colo suffered its first institutional crisis due to financial problems, which led to a salary reduction for first team footballers and board members, with their consequent resistance.Salinas, Sebastián (2005), p. 309. That season the team played another tournament final against [[Audax Italiano]]. However, due to a platform collapse at Estadio Italiano and the subsequent bracas between the fans, it was decided the game suspension. In that moment, Colo-Colo were winning 2–1. That day's tragedy resulted in 130 injuries and three deaths. The match was canceled and the champion position for that year remained vacant.Salinas, Sebastián (2005), pp. 299–300. Other authors however declared that both [[Audax Italiano]] and Colo-Colo were declared champions.Larraín, Fernando (1940), p. 38.La Nación (1985), pp. 12 and 32. ===1933–1973: Beginnings in professional football=== In 1933, Colo-Colo alongside six clubs from [[Santiago de Chile|Santiago]] decided to create the [[Chilean Primera División|Chilean professional football league]].Salinas, Sebastián (2005), p. 327. On 23 July, the team won the [[Campeonato de Apertura (Chile)|Campeonato de Apertura]] ([[Copa Chile]] precursor), after defeating 2–1 to [[Unión Española]]. However, in the first [[Chilean Primera División|Primera División]] official tournament, Colo-Colo finished first alongside [[C.D. Magallanes|Magallanes]], which forced the "Cacique" to play a tie-breaker match. That match was lost 2–1 by Colo-Colo.{{cite web |first= Eduardo | last= Espina |year= 2005 |url = http://rsssf.com/tablesc/chile33.html |title = Chile 1933 |work = Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation ([[RSSSF]]) |accessdate = 2007}} In 1937 the team was undefeated,Marín, Edgardo (1988), p. 33. and reached its first league title.{{cite web |first= Eduardo | last= Espina |year= 2005 |url = http://rsssf.com/tablesc/chile37.html |title = Chile 1937 |work = Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation ([[RSSSF]]) |accessdate = 2007}} Two seasons later, in 1939, Colo-Colo won for second time a league title, now under the guidance of the Hungarian coach [[Francisco Platko]],Marín, Edgardo (1988), p. 43. and with [[Alfonso Domínguez]] as goalscorer with 20 goals in 24 matches.Marín, Edgardo (1988), p. 42. After another title in 1941 with Platko as coach,{{cite web |first= Eduardo | last= Espina |year= 2005 |url = http://rsssf.com/tablesc/chile41.html |title = Chile 1941 |work = Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation ([[RSSSF]]) |accessdate = 2007}} the club went on to win the titles of 1944{{cite web |first= Eduardo | last= Espina |year= 2005 |url = http://rsssf.com/tablesc/chile44.html |title = Chile 1944 |work = Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation ([[RSSSF]]) |accessdate = 2007}} and 1947.{{cite web |first= Eduardo | last= Espina |year= 2005 |url = http://rsssf.com/tablesc/chile47.html |title = Chile 1947 |work = Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation ([[RSSSF]]) |accessdate = 2007}} The following year Colo-Colo organized the [[South American Club Championship (football)|South American Club Championship]] – [[Copa Libertadores]] background – in Santiago,{{cite web |first = Esteban | last = Bekerman |year = 2008 |url = http://www.perfil.com/contenidos/2008/03/13/noticia_0054.html |title = Hace 60 años, River perdía la gran chance de ser el primer club campeón de América |work = Perfil.com |accessdate = 10 May 2008}} which brought together the 1947 continent’s champions. In 1945, the club had the worst season in its history, finishing penultimate in eleventh place only ahead of weak [[Badminton F.C.|Badminton]].{{cite web |first= Eduardo | last= Espina |year= 2005 |url = http://rsssf.com/tablesc/chile45.html |title = Chile 1945 |work = Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation ([[RSSSF]]) |accessdate = 2007}} In the early 1950s, club's president Antonio Labán hired [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] striker [[George Robledo]], paying [[£]]25,000 for its signing.Marín, Edgardo y Salviat, Julio (1975), p. 105. Robledo’s performances led the team to the titles of 1953{{cite web |first= Eduardo | last= Espina |year= 2005 |url = http://rsssf.com/tablesc/chile53.html |title = Chile 1953 |work = Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation ([[RSSSF]]) |accessdate = 2007}} and 1956.{{cite web |first= Eduardo | last= Espina |year= 2005 |url = http://rsssf.com/tablesc/chile56.html |title = Chile 1956 |work = Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation ([[RSSSF]]) |accessdate = 2007}} During that age, the club acquired a terrain at [[Macul]], where began the construction of [[Estadio Monumental David Arellano|Estadio Monumental]].Marín, Edgardo y Salviat, Julio (1975), p. 119. Besides the acquisition, the directive invested in a headquarters located at [[Santiago Centro]] (located at Cienfuegos 41) in 1953. The next decade Colo-Colo win the titles of 1960{{cite web |first= Eduardo | last= Espina |year= 2005 |url = http://rsssf.com/tablesc/chile60.html |title = Chile 1960 |work = Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation ([[RSSSF]]) |accessdate = 2007}} and 1963.{{cite web |first= Eduardo | last= Espina |year= 2005 |url = http://rsssf.com/tablesc/chile63.html |title = Chile 1963 |work = Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation ([[RSSSF]]) |accessdate = 2007}} The 1963 team broke two top-tier records: [[Luis Hernán Álvarez]] scored 37 goals in a single seasonMarín, Edgardo y Salviat, Julio (1975), p. 130. (the highest number of goals scored by a Colo-Colo footballer during a season) and the netting of the highest number of goals scored by a club in a season (130).Marín, Edgardo y Salviat, Julio (1975), p. 131. The team won its tenth honour in 1970.Marín, Edgardo y Salviat, Julio (1975), p. 160. === Colo-Colo 1973 and 1980s dominance === In 1972, now under the orders of coach [[Luis Álamos]] Marín, Edgardo y Salviat, Julio (1975), p. 188. and with figures like [[Carlos Caszely]] and [[Francisco Valdés]],Marín, Edgardo (1988), p. 250. the club won another championship.{{cite web |first= Eduardo | last= Espina |year= 2005 |url = http://rsssf.com/tablesc/chile72.html |title = Chile 1972 |work = Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation ([[RSSSF]]) |accessdate = 2007}} It also obtained the country's attendance record of 45,929 people for a single season.{{cite web |year= 2005 |url = http://rsssf.com/tablesc/chile72.html |title = Especial Colo Colo 1972 |work = Minuto 90 |accessdate = 2013}} That team was the basis of the so-called "Colo-Colo 73", the first Chilean team to reach a Copa Libertadores final, where it lost against [[Club Atlético Independiente|Independiente]] of Argentina.Marín, Edgardo y Salviat, Julio (1975), p. 193. After Colo-Colo's brilliant campaign, the club went into a competitiveness and institutional crisis not being able to win another league title until 1979.{{cite web |first= Eduardo | last= Espina |year= 2005 |url = http://rsssf.com/tablesc/chile79.html |title = Chile 1979 |work = Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation ([[RSSSF]]) |accessdate = 2007}} That team featured the talented Brazilian midfielder [[Severino Vasconcelos]] alongside a returning Caszely.Marín, Edgardo (1988), p. 298. Nevertheless, in 1975, the construction of Estadio Monumental was finished and the stadium was inaugurated in a league match against [[Deportes Aviación]], but due to problems with the infrastructure and other basic services the stadium was indefinitely closed. In the 1980s, the club obtained the league titles of 1981 and 1983{{cite web |first= Eduardo | last= Espina |year= 2005 |url = http://rsssf.com/tablesc/chile81.html |title = Chile 1981 |work = Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation ([[RSSSF]]) |accessdate = 2007}} with coach [[Pedro García Barros|Pedro García]], and the 1986{{cite web |first= Eduardo | last= Espina |year= 2005 |url = http://rsssf.com/tablesc/chile86.html |title = Chile 1986 |work = Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation ([[RSSSF]]) |accessdate = 2007}} and 1989{{cite web |first= Eduardo | last= Espina |year= 2005 |url = http://rsssf.com/tablesc/chile89.html |title = Chile 1989 |work = Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation ([[RSSSF]]) |accessdate = 2007}} honours under [[Arturo Salah]]. The 1987 [[Alianza Lima air disaster]] claimed the lives of sixteen players and Colo-Colo was the first to help the Peruvian team, loaning them 4 players.{{cite web | title = En Perú conmemoran 25 años de la tragedia área que enlutó a Alianza Lima | url = http://www.latercera.com/noticia/deportes/2012/12/656-497527-9-en-peru-conmemoran-25-anos-de-la-tragedia-aerea-que-enluto-a-alianza-lima.shtml | publisher = La Tercera |date=8 December 2012 }} Nonetheless the team won four Copa Chile titles in that decade. During that period, the greatest disappointment was at the continental tournament level with the team only exceeding the first stage in the [[1988 Copa Libertadores]]. On September 30, 1989, the Estadio Monumental was re-inaugurated in an exhibition match against [[CA Peñarol|Peñarol]], which Colo-Colo won 2–1 with goals by [[Marcelo Barticciotto]] and [[Leonel Herrera Silva|Leonel Herrera]], the son of a 1970s legendary former defender of the same name. === 1991–1999: International success === [[File:Camiseta Colo-Colo 91.jpg|190px|thumbnail|Colo-Colo's uniform at the [[1991 Copa Libertadores Finals]]]] The 1990s was the most successful decade in the club's history for the national and international honours achieved. Croatian [[Mirko Jozić]] arrived as coach, leading the team towards its first ''Bicampeonato'' for winning two national titles in a row.{{cite web |first= Eduardo | last= Espina |year= 2005 |url = http://rsssf.com/tablesc/chile90.html |title = Chile 1990 |work = Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation ([[RSSSF]]) |accessdate = 2007}} On June 5, 1991, after beating [[Club Olimpia|Olimpia]] 3–0 at Monumental with two goals by [[Luis Pérez (Chilean footballer)|Luis Pérez]] and one by [[Leonel Herrera Silva|Leonel Herrera]], Colo-Colo became the first Chilean team to win a [[Copa Libertadores 1991|Copa Libertadores]]. That same season, the "Albos" lost the [[Intercontinental Cup (football)|Intercontinental Cup]] final against Yugoslavian club [[Red Star Belgrade]], after being defeated 3–0 in Tokyo.{{cite web |date = 23 October 2008 |url = http://www.dalealbo.cl/copa-intercontinental-1991-estrella-roja-3-0-colo- |title = Copa Intercontinental 1991: Estrella Roja 3–0 Colo Colo |work = Dalealbo.cl |accessdate = 23 March 2013}} At the local level, the club won the 1991 league, its third-consecutive title thus achieving its first ''Tricampeonato''.{{cite web |first= Eduardo | last= Espina |year= 2005 |url = http://rsssf.com/tablesc/chile91.html |title = Chile 1991 |work = Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation ([[RSSSF]]) |accessdate = 2007}} The following season, the club won the [[1992 Recopa Sudamericana|Recopa Sudamericana]], after beating Brazil's [[Cruzeiro Esporte Clube|Cruzeiro]] in a penalty shootout, and also obtained the [[1992 Copa Interamericana|Copa Interamericana]], after winning 3–1 against [[Puebla FC|Puebla]] in Mexico. The last title won by Jozić in Colo-Colo was the 1993 league title, thus closing a successful spell in South America.{{cite web |first= Eduardo | last= Espina |year= 2005 |url = http://rsssf.com/tablesc/chile93.html |title = Chile 1993 |work = Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation ([[RSSSF]]) |accessdate = 2007}} After Jozić's departure came a little drought in national titles, but the team managed to get an unforgettable 3-0 win over arch rivals Universidad de Chile in 1995. The team was champion of the 1994 [[Copa Chile 1994|Copa Chile]] and reached the 1994 [[1994 Copa Libertadores|Copa Libertadores]] quarterfinals. The following season saw the arrival of Paraguayan coach [[Gustavo Benítez]], who obtained the 1996,{{cite web |first= Eduardo | last= Espina |year= 2005 |url = http://rsssf.com/tablesc/chile96.html |title = Chile 1996 |work = Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation ([[RSSSF]]) |accessdate = 2007}} 1997-C{{cite web |first= Eduardo | last= Espina |year= 2005 |url = http://rsssf.com/tablesc/chile97.html |title = Chile 1997 |work = Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation ([[RSSSF]]) |accessdate = 2007}} and 1998{{cite web |first= Eduardo | last= Espina |year= 2005 |url = http://rsssf.com/tablesc/chile98.html |title = Chile 1998 |work = Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation ([[RSSSF]]) |accessdate = 2007}} league titles. The team advanced to the semifinals of the [[Supercopa Libertadores]] in [[1996 Supercopa Libertadores|1996]], and of the Copa Libertadores in [[1997 Copa Libertadores|1997]], being eliminated both times by Cruzeiro. In 1999, Colo-Colo relived something like 1994, finishing fourth in the Chilean league and having three coaches during that single season: Brazilian [[Nelsinho Baptista]], the caretaker manager Carlos Durán and then [[Fernando Morena]] of Uruguay, who remained until 2001. === 1999–present: Bankruptcy and recovery === In 1999, after Benítez's departure, the club entered a serious financial crisis. In 23 January 2002, after years of economic mismanagement under the leadership of Peter Dragicevic as president,{{cite web |first= Pedro Pablo | last= Vivanco del Río |url = http://www.todoalbo.cl/el-club/historia/ |title = Historia de Colo-Colo en Internet |work = Todoalbo.cl |accessdate = 23 March 2013}} the club was declared bankrupt. Justice named Juan Carlos Saffie as syndic responsible for the institution allowing it not to lose its legal status. Despite the bankruptcy, under [[Jaime Pizarro]] as coach – key player in the obtaining of the [[1991 Copa Libertadores]] – Los Albos won the [[2002 Chilean Primera División season|Torneo de Clausura]], with an almost completely juvenile squad.{{cite web |first= Eduardo | last= Espina |year= 2005 |url = http://rsssf.com/tablesc/chile02.html |title = Chile 2002 |work = Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation ([[RSSSF]]) |accessdate = 2007}} Three years later, in 2005, the joint-stock company Blanco y Negro{{cite web |author = Sitio Oficial de Colo-Colo |year = 2013 |url = http://www.colocolo.cl/arturo-salah-asumio-como-nuevo-presidente-de-colo-colo/ |title = Información Corporativa Club Social y Deportivo Colo Colo 2013 |language = |accessdate = 25 April 2013}} took over the administration, concessioning all club assets for thirty years in exchange for paying all debts through an opening process at the [[Santiago Stock Exchange]]. In the first half of 2006, the judiciary court declared the bankruptcy over. [[File:Colo Colo Campeón 2006.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Colo-Colo squad celebrating the [[Chilean Primera División|2006 Torneo de Clausura]] obtaining.]] With the Argentine [[Claudio Borghi]] as coach since 2006, and with players like [[Matías Fernández]] and [[Humberto Suazo]], Colo-Colo obtained a ''Bicampeonato'' winning the [[Chilean Apertura Tournament|Apertura]]{{cite web | date= 21 February 2008 |url = http://papeldigital.info/ltdep/edicion.html?20060703010022 | title = Bravo por el eterno campeón | work= Papel Digital}} and [[Chilean Primera División|Clausura]] tournaments.{{cite web | date= 20 February 2008 |url = http://papeldigital.info/ltdep/edicion.html?20061225010022 | title = Festejo entre copas | work= Papel Digital}} The squad reached another international final, the [[2006 Copa Sudamericana|Copa Sudamericana]], losing 2–1 to Mexico's side [[CF Pachuca|Pachuca]]. That season, ''El Cacique'' was recognized by the [[IFFHS]] as the world's club of the month.{{cite web | date= 20 October 2006 |url = http://www.iffhs.de/?3d4d443d0b803e8b447cce02285fdcdc3bfcdc0aec70aeedbc08 | title = The world's club of the month | publisher = [[IFFHS]]}} The following season Colo-Colo won two more consecutive tournaments, winning a ''Tetracampeonato'' for winning four back-to-back championships, being the first Chilean team to achieve that.{{cite web |url = http://papeldigital.info/ltdep/edicion.html?20071224010022 |title = Blanca Navidad | publisher = La Tercera |accessdate = 20 February 2008}} After Borghi's departure, the club obtained its 28th title after defeating [[CD Palestino|Palestino]] in the [[Torneo de Clausura de Chile 2008|2008 Torneo de Clausura]] finals under the coaching of [[Marcelo Barticciotto]], and with [[Lucas Barrios]] as principal scorer, who equaled Luis Hernán Álvarez's record of highest number of goals scored by a Colo-Colo footballer during a single season with 37 goals.{{cite web |url = http://www.terra.cl/deportes/index.cfm?accion=futbolnacional&id_reg=1090066&XjWpZ=PqZ23&titulo_url=%A1Colo_Colo_campeon!_Logro_su_estrella_28_con_historico_goleador |title = ¡Colo Colo campeón! Logró su estrella 28 con histórico goleador | publisher = La Tercera |date = 20 December 2008}} The following season, the club became the first professional team to play on [[Easter Island]].{{cite web |url = http://es.fifa.com/worldfootball/news/newsid=1086835.html |title = Juego del siglo en Rapa Nui | publisher = [[FIFA.com]] |date = 6 August 2009}} After a poor [[Torneo de Apertura de Chile 2009|Torneo de Apertura 2009]] – not reaching the play-offs for the first time – Los Albos started the Clausura very close to relegation positions. However, the team reached the tournament's finals against Universidad Católica, beating them 4–2 in [[Estadio Santa Laura-Universidad SEK|Santa Laura]], with players like [[Esteban Paredes]], [[Macnelly Torres]] and [[Ezequiel Miralles]], coached by [[Hugo Tocalli]].{{cite web |url = http://www.emol.com/noticias/deportes/detalle/detallenoticias.asp?idnoticia=387952 |title = No hay caso con Colo-Colo de amenazado con el descenso a campeón | publisher = Emol.com |date = 9 December 2009}} Colo-Colo's last championship was in 2014 after winning the [[2013–14 Campeonato Nacional season|Torneo de Clausura]]. It was the team's 30th Chilean League title. ==Badge, colours and kit== [[File:Cacique Colo-Colo.jpg|thumb|180px|[[Colocolo (tribal chief)|Colocolo]] bust at [[Estadio Monumental David Arellano]]]] {{Details|Uniform of Colo-Colo|Badge of Colo-Colo}} The club's badge represents [[Mapuche]] chieftain [[Colocolo (tribal chief)|Colo Colo]], an important Wall Mapu member who battled in the [[Arauco War]] against the [[Spanish empire]] (1536–1818).{{cite web |date = 19 April 2012 |url = http://www.elamaule.cl/noticia/deporte/87anoscolocolo-conoce-quien-fue-el-cacique-colo-colo |title = Historia del mapuche Colocolo |publisher = El Maule |accessdate = 10 April 2013}} On 19 April 1925, when the club was established, Luis Contreras – one of the players that founded the club – defined the team's badge, in representation of the chief and the country's indigenous people. Throughout its history, Colo-Colo’s uniform has been a white shirt and black shorts. The uniform was originally designed by Juan Quiñones following the recommendations of [[David Arellano]]. In 1927, after Arellano’s died while playing against Real Unión Deportiva (currently [[Real Valladolid]]), it was decided then that the badge will wear a black horizontal band over it forever, to represent the institution's eternal mourning. The team’s away kits have varied through its history, from green between 1927 and the mid-1970s and to red from 1975 to 1988. ==Stadium== {{Main article|Estadio Monumental David Arellano}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Estadio Monumental | nickname = Pedreros | image = [[File:Estadio Monumental 2009.jpg|frameless|Estadio Monumental after its expansion completed in 2009.|alt=A semi-panoramic view of the stadium. The seats are white and black, and shows the club badge in the seats. The roof of the stand is supported by a cantilever structure, in a "buried" construction.]] | location = [[Vicuña Mackenna Avenue]],
[[Macul]],
[[Santiago]],
Chile | broke_ground = 1975 | opened = 30 September 1989 | owner = Colo-Colo | operator = Colo-Colo | cost = [[US$]]1.5 million (1989) | architect = [[Mario Recordón]] (1975) | tenants = Colo-Colo (1989–present) | seating_capacity = 47,347 seated{{cite web |author = |year = 2011 |url = http://www.todoalbo.cl/estadio-monumental/ |title = Estadio Monumental |work= Todoalbo.cl |language = |accessdate = 1 April 2013}} }} Colo-Colo initially played on a field called Estadio El Llano but in January 1928 moved to the [[Estadio Campos de Sports de Ñuñoa|Campos de Sports de Ñuñoa]]. The team later moved to [[Estadio Nacional Julio Martínez|Estadio Nacional]] where it played from 1939 to the late 1980s. In 1946 the club bought a stadium from [[Carabineros de Chile]] – then called ''Fortín Mapocho'' – which was closed according security reasons. It was intended to build a 30,000 seat stadium at the site. However, a municipal ordinance prohibited construction in the area. For that reason, Colo-Colo sold the stadium in order to raise funds for the future [[Estadio Monumental David Arellano|Estadio Monumental]]. In 1956, club's president Antonio Labán acquired a 28 [[Hectare|ha]] terrain at [[Macul]], close to the intersection between [[Vicuña Mackenna Avenue|Vicuña Mackenna]] and Departamental. The new stadium was originally planned with a capacity of 120,000. Due to the work's high cost and lack of a government subsidy the project was halted. In 1960, after Chile's successful proposition to hold the [[1962 FIFA World Cup|World Cup]], several congressmen proposed to build a 52,000-seat stadium at Colo-Colo's site. However, the [[1960 Valdivia earthquake|9.5 Valdivia earthquake]] and a willingness from congress stopped the initiative. Colo-Colo's brilliant campaigns in 1972 and 1973 allowed the stadium construction to resume. It was inaugurated in a league match 1975 which Colo-Colo win 1–0 over [[Deportes Aviación]] with [[Juan Carlos Orellana]], who become the first player to score a goal in Monumental's history.{{cite web|url = http://www.colocolo.cl/estadio-monumental/monumental/historia/ |title = Una historia monumental |publisher= Colocolo.cl |accessdate = 13 September 2015}} However, the stadium was closed due to lack of basic services and infrastructure. It was not reopened until 1989 thanks to [[Hugo Rubio]]'s transfer to [[Bologna F.C. 1909|Bologna]] which allowed the club to receive [[US$]]1 million to repair the problems mentioned. The stadium was called ''Monumental [[David Arellano]]'' in honour of its founder and its definitive inauguration was in a match against Uruguay's [[CA Peñarol|Peñarol]] which Colo-Colo won 2–1. Since its definitive opening, the stadium has seen the [[1991 Copa Libertadores]] and [[1992 Copa Interamericana]] titles as well as several league honors. Monumental's public record attendance was in 1992 for a derby match with [[Club Universidad de Chile|Universidad de Chile]] which registered an attendance of 70,000 fans approximately.{{cite web |publisher= Biblioteca del Congreso Nacional de Chile |year= 1994 |url = http://www.bcn.cl/obtienearchivo?id=recursoslegales/10221.3/22919/1/HL19327.pdf |title = Historia de la Ley Nº 19.327. Fija normas para prevención y sanción de hechos de violencia en recintos deportivos con ocasión de espectáculos de futbol profesional |work = Diario Oficial |accessdate = 7 July 2007}} That record was closely followed in August 1993 during a 2–0 exhibition match win over [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] with a 67,543 attendance.{{cite web |publisher = EFE |year = 1993 |url = http://hemeroteca.abcdesevilla.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/sevilla/abc.sevilla/1993/08/23/076.html |title= 2-0: Derrota del Real Madrid ante Colo-Colo |work = Diario ABC |accessdate = 7 July 2007}} Several remodeling works and stricter security brought down the total capacity to 47,347. The [[Chile national football team|Chilean national team]] usually use the stadium for its games since 1997.{{cite web |publisher= Prensa Fútbol |date= 5 September 2009|url = http://www.prensafutbol.cl/reportajes/43-reportajes/8649-chile-vs-venezuela-a-repetir-la-magica-noche-del-monumental-.html |title = Chile vs. Venezuela: A repetir la mágica noche Monumental |accessdate = 19 April 2013}} The stadium was also used during the [[2015 Copa América]]. ==Players== {{Colo-Colo squad|format=table}} ===2018 Winter transfers=== ====In==== {{Fs start}} {{Fs player|no=9|nat=CHI|pos=MF|name=[[Esteban Pavez]]|other=from [[Atlético Paranaense]]}} {{Fs player|no=15|nat=ARG|pos=DF|name=[[Damián Pérez]]|other=from [[Club Tijuana|Tijuana]]}} {{Fs mid}} {{Fs player|no=30|nat=VEN|pos=FW|name=[[Danny Pérez]]|other=loaned from [[Deportes La Serena]]}} {{Fs player|no=33|nat=PAR|pos=FW|name=[[Lucas Barrios]]|other=from [[Argentinos Juniors]]}} {{Fs end}} ====Out==== {{Fs start}} {{Fs player|no= 3|nat=CHI|pos=MF|name=[[Bryan Carvallo]]|other=to [[Club Necaxa|Necaxa]]}} {{Fs player|no= 9|nat=URU|pos=FW|name=[[Octavio Rivero]]|other=to [[Club Atlas|Atlas]]}} {{Fs player|no=22|nat=CHI|pos=FW|name=[[Nicolás Orellana]]|other=Released}} {{Fs mid}} {{Fs player|no=33|nat=CHI|pos=FW|name=[[Zederick Vega]]|other=loaned to [[San Antonio Unido]]}} {{Fs player|no=41|nat=CHI|pos=MF|name=[[Luciano Díaz (Chilean footballer)|Luciano Díaz]]|other=loaned to [[San Antonio Unido]]}} {{Fs end}} ==Managers== {{main article|List of Colo-Colo managers}} ===Current coaching staff=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Position !! Name |- |Head Coach ||{{flagicon|CHI}} [[Héctor Tapia]] |- |Assistant Manager ||{{flagicon|PAR}} [[Gualberto Jara]] |- |Assistant Manager ||{{flagicon|CHI}} [[Claudio Maldonado]] |- |Assistant Manager ||{{flagicon|CHI}} [[Marco Muñoz]] |- |Fitness coach ||{{flagicon|CHI}} [[Hernán Torres Muñoz|Hernán Torres]] |- |Fitness coach ||{{flagicon|CHI}} [[Rubén Bascuñan]] |- |Goalkeeping coach ||{{flagicon|URU}} [[Claudio Arbiza]] |- |Head Doctor || {{flagicon|CHI}} [[Roberto Yañez]] |- |Physio || {{flagicon|CHI}} [[Wilson Ferrada]] |- |Physio ||{{flagicon|CHI}} [[Rocco Rienzi]] |- |u19 Coach ||{{flagicon|CHI}} [[ Luis Pérez Ramírez|Luis Pérez]] |} ==Supporters and rivalries== {{Main article|Garra Blanca}} Colo-Colo is the club with the largest following in Chile, with approximately 42% of the total [[Football in Chile|Chilean football]] fans according to research published in August 2012 by Spanish newspaper agency [[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]].{{cite web | url = http://www.marca.com/2012/07/23/futbol/futbol_internacional/chile/1343054579.html | title = Chile es del 'Colo' aunque gane la 'U' | publisher = [[Marca.com]] |date = 23 August 2012}} The study showed a 4% growth in comparison to 2006 research by Fundación Futuro that ranked the club in first place with the 38% of the preferences, leaving its rival Universidad de Chile in second place.{{cite web | url = http://www.fundacionfuturo.cl/admin/publicos/Mundial.pdf | title = Mundial | work = Fundación Futuro |date = 31 October 2007}} Since the early 1960s, the club has had organized fan groups, which evolved in the mid-1980s into the so-called ''[[Garra Blanca]]''. They attended Colo-Colo's games and generally rioted, especially in derbies, turning [[Estadio Monumental David Arellano|Estadio Monumental]] surroundings into battlefields against the [[Carabineros de Chile|military police]]. In 2000, the group was declared as [[Barra brava]]. ==Honours== ===Domestic=== *''' [[Asociación de Fútbol de Santiago|Liga Central de Football / Asociación de Fútbol de Santiago]]: 4''' **1925, 1928, 1929, 1930 *'''[[Chilean Primera División|Primera División]]: 32''' **1937, 1939, 1941, 1944, 1947, 1953, 1956, 1960, [[1963 Primera División de Chile|1963]], 1970, 1972, 1979, 1981, 1983, 1986, 1989,
